coredata.dc:title: Singlet deformation and non(anti)commutative N=2 supersymmetric U(1) gauge theory
coredata.dc:creator: Araki, Takeo
Ito, Katsushi
coredata.dc:description: AbstractWe study N=2 supersymmetric U(1) gauge theory in non(anti)commutative N=2 harmonic superspace with the singlet deformation, which preserves chirality. We construct a Lagrangian which is invariant under both the deformed gauge and supersymmetry transformations. We find the field redefinition such that the N=2 vector multilplet transforms canonically under the deformed symmetries.

head.ce:title: Singlet deformation and non(anti)commutative N=2 supersymmetric U(1) gauge theory

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Physics, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8578, Japan

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Physics, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo 152-8551, Japan

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We study N=2 supersymmetric U(1) gauge theory in non(anti)commutative N=2 harmonic superspace with the singlet deformation, which preserves chirality. We construct a Lagrangian which is invariant under both the deformed gauge and supersymmetry transformations. We find the field redefinition such that the N=2 vector multilplet transforms canonically under the deformed symmetries.

ce:sections.ce:para: Non(anti)commutative superspace [1] with nonanticommutativity in Grassmann odd coordinates appears in superstrings compactified on CalabiâYau threefold in the graviphoton background [2â4]. The low-energy effective theory on the D-brane is realized by supersymmetric gauge theories in non(anti)commutative superspace. Perturabative and nonperturabative aspects of these gauge theories have been studied extensively [5â8]. It is an interesting problem to study the deformation of extended superspace since it admits a variety of deformation parameters [9]. The deformation of extended superspace has been recently studied in [10â15]. In a previous paper [12], we have studied the deformed Lagrangian explicitly in the component formalism up to the first order in the deformation parameter C. Since the Lagrangian get higher order correction in C, the full Lagrangian is rather complicated. Moreover, the harmonic superspace formalism introduces the infinite number of auxiliary fields. In order to preserve the WZ gauge in the deformed theory, the gauge transformation has also correction in the form of power series in C.

There exist some interesting cases where the deformation structure becomes simple. One is the limit to the N=1/2 superspace [5], where the action should reduce to N=1/2 super-YangâMills theory with adjoint matter. Another interesting case is the singlet deformation [10,11], where the deformation parameters belongs to the singlet representation of the R-symmetry group SU(2)R. In this Letter, we will study N=2 supersymmetric U(1) gauge theory in the harmonic superspace with singlet deformation. In this case, the gauge and supersymmetry transformations get correction linear in the deformation parameter. Therefore we can easily perform the field redefinition such that the component fields transform canonically under the gauge transformation. In the case of N=1/2 super-YangâMills theory, such field redefinition is also possible [5]. But in this case the component fields do not transform canonically under the deformed supersymmtery transformation. In the singlet case, we will show that there is a field redefinition such that the redefined fields also transform canonically under the deformed supersymmetry. We will construct a deformed Lagrangian which is invariant under both the gauge and supersymmetry transformations. We find that the deformed Lagrangian is characterized by a single function of an antiholomorphic scalar field.

We begin with reviewing the non(anti)commutative deformation of N=2 harmonic superspace [10â12]. The N=2 harmonic superspace [16] has coordinates (xÎ¼,Î¸Î±i,Î¸ÌÎ±Ìi,uÂ±i), where Î¼=0,1,2,3 are spacetime indices, Î±,Î±Ì=1,2 spinor indices and i=1,2 SU(2)R indices. We will consider the Euclidean signature of spacetime. For lowering and raising spinor indices, we use an antisymmetric tensor ÎµÎ±Î² with Îµ12=âÎµ12=1, while for SU(2)R indices, we use Ïµij with Ïµ12=âÏµ12=â1. The coordinates (xÎ¼,Î¸Î±i,Î¸ÌÎ±Ìi) are those of N=2 rigid superspace. The bosonic variables uÂ±i, called the harmonic variables, form an SU(2) matrix satisfying u+iuâi=1 and u+i=uâi. The harmonic variables are necessary for the off-shell formulation of supersymmetric field theories with extended supersymmetry as developed in [16]. The supersymmetry generators QiÎ±, QÌÎ±Ìi and the supercovariant derivatives DÎ±i, DÌÎ±Ìi are defined by (1)QÎ±i=ââÎ¸Î±iâiÏÎ¼Î±Î±ÌÎ¸ÌÎ±ÌiââxÎ¼,QÌÎ±Ìi=âââÎ¸ÌÎ±Ìi+iÎ¸Î±iÏÎ¼Î±Î±ÌââxÎ¼,DÎ±i=ââÎ¸Î±i+iÏÎ¼Î±Î±ÌÎ¸ÌÎ±ÌiââxÎ¼,DÌÎ±Ìi=âââÎ¸ÌÎ±ÌiâiÎ¸Î±iÏÎ¼Î±Î±ÌââxÎ¼. In the harmonic superspace, we use the supercovariant derivatives (2)DÂ±Î±=uÂ±iDiÎ±,DÌÂ±Î±=uÂ±iDÌiÎ±, which are U(1)-projected by using uÂ±i. For the off-shell formulation of field theories, the basic ingredient is the analytic superfield Î¦ satisfying D+Î±Î¦=DÌ+Î±ÌÎ¦=0. The solution of these constraints can be conveniently written of the form Î¦=Î¦(xÎ¼A,Î¸+,Î¸Ì+,u) by introducing analytic coordinates (3)xAÎ¼=xÎ¼âiÎ¸iÏÎ¼Î¸Ìj+Î¸jÏÎ¼Î¸Ìiu+iuâj=xÎ¼âiÎ¸+ÏÎ¼Î¸Ìâ+Î¸âÏÎ¼Î¸Ì+,(4)Î¸Â±Î±=uÂ±iÎ¸iÎ±,Î¸ÌÂ±Î±Ì=uÂ±iÎ¸ÌiÎ±Ì.

We now introduce the nonanticommutativity in the N=2 harmonic superspace by using the â-product: (5)Î¸Î±i,Î¸Î²jâ=CÎ±Î²ij, with some constants CÎ±Î²ij. We assume that the chiral coordinates xLÎ¼â¡xÎ¼+iÎ¸iÏÎ¼Î¸Ìi and Î¸ÌÎ±Ìi (anti)commute with other coordinates (6)xÎ¼L,xÎ½Lâ=xÎ¼L,Î¸Î±iâ=xÎ¼L,Î¸ÌÎ±Ìiâ=0,Î¸ÌÎ±Ìi,Î¸ÌÎ²Ìjâ=Î¸ÌÎ±Ìi,Î¸Î±jâ=0. Here the â-product realizing this non(anti)commutativity is defined by (7)fâg(Î¸)=f(Î¸)exp(P)g(Î¸),P=â12QiÎ±CÎ±Î²ijQjÎ². The Poisson structure P commutes with the supercovariant derivatives. This deformation preserves chirality. The constants CÎ±Î²ij is a symmetric property CÎ±Î²ij=CÎ²Î±ji and can be decomposed of the form: (8)CÎ±Î²ij=CÎ±Î²(ij)+14ÏµijÎµÎ±Î²Cs. Here the first term CÎ±Î²(ij) is symmetric with respect to i and j (and also Î± and Î²). The second term is antisymmetric and is called the singlet deformation introduced in [10,11]. In [11] the deformation with the Poisson structure P=â18ÎµÎ±Î²ÏµijCsDiÎ±DjÎ² has been studied. In this Letter we will consider the â-product (7) with the singlet deformation parameter [10]: (9)P=â18ÎµÎ±Î²ÏµijCsQiÎ±QjÎ².

The action of N=2 supersymmetric U(1) gauge theory in this non(anti)commutative harmonic superspace is written in terms of an analytic superfield V++ [17]: (10)S=12ân=2â(âi)nnâ«d4xd8Î¸du1â¯dunV++(Î¶1,u1)ââ¯âV++(Î¶n,un)(u+1u+2)â¯(u+nu+1) where Î¶i=(xA,Î¸+i,Î¸Ì+i) and d8Î¸=d4Î¸+d4Î¸â with d4Î¸Â±=d2Î¸Â±d2Î¸ÌÂ±. The harmonic integral â«du is defined as in [16]. The action (10) is invariant under the gauge transformation (11)Î´âÎV++=âD++Î+iÎ,V++â, where the gauge parameter Î(Î¶,u) is also analytic. D++ denotes the harmonic derivative D++=u+iââuâiâ2iÎ¸+ÏÎ¼Î¸Ì+ââxAÎ¼+Î¸+Î±ââÎ¸âÎ±+Î¸Ì+Î±ÌââÎ¸ÌâÎ±Ì. When an analytic superfield is expanded in the Grassmann coordinates, each component field has a harmonic expansion with respect to uÂ±i. The analytic superfield V++ therefore contains infinitely many auxiliary fields. Since the gauge parameter Î also includes infinitely many fields, one can remove unnecessary auxiliary fields as in the commutative case. We then arrive at the WessâZumino (WZ) gauge: (12)V++WZ(Î¶,u)=âi2Î¸+2ÏÌ(xA)+i2Î¸Ì+2Ï(xA)â2iÎ¸+ÏÎ¼Î¸Ì+AÎ¼(xA)+4Î¸Ì+2Î¸+Ïi(xA)uâiâ4Î¸+2Î¸Ì+ÏÌi(xA)uâi+3Î¸+2Î¸Ì+2Dij(xA)uâiuâj. In [12], we have computed the O(C) action (10) in the WZ gauge explicitly. In the singlet case, the order O(Cs) Lagrangian reads L=L(0)+L(1), where (13)L(0)=â14FÎ¼Î½FÎ¼Î½+FÌÎ¼Î½âiÏiÏÎ¼âÎ¼ÏÌiââÎ¼ÏâÎ¼ÏÌ+14DijDij,L(1)=12CsAÎ½âÎ¼ÏÌFÎ¼Î½+FÌÎ¼Î½+i2CsÏÌÏkÏÎ½âÎ½ÏÌk+i2CsÏkÏÎ½ÏÌkâÎ½ÏÌâi2CsÎµÎ±Î²AÎ¼ÏÎ¼ÏÌkÎ±ÏÎ½âÎ½ÏÌkÎ²+i2CsÏÌiÏÌjDij+24CsAÎ¼AÎ¼â2ÏÌâ24CsÏÌDijDij, where FÌÎ¼Î½â¡i2ÎµÎ¼Î½ÏÏFÏÏ. Note that L(0) is the undeformed Lagrangian.

In the commutative case, the gauge transformation with the gauge parameter Î»(xA) preserves the WZ gauge. But for generic CÎ±Î²ij, Î»(xA) does not. In [12], we have constructed the gauge parameter Î(Î¶,u) which preserves the WZ gauge, which is an infinite power series in the deformation parameter C. We will see now the deformed gauge transformation in the singlet case more explicitly. For later convenience, we begin with the deformed gauge transformation (11) of V++WZ with the most general analytic gauge parameter Î(Î¶,u): (14)Î(Î¶,u)=Î»(0,0)(xA,u)+Î¸Ì+Î±ÌÎ»(0,1)Î±Ì(xA,u)+Î¸+Î±Î»(1,0)Î±(xA,u)+Î¸Ì+2Î»(0,2)(xA,u)+Î¸+2Î»(2,0)(xA,u)+Î¸+ÏÎ¼Î¸Ì+Î»Î¼(1,1)(xA,u)+Î¸Ì+2Î¸+Î±Î»(1,2)Î±(xA,u)+Î¸+2Î¸Ì+Î±ÌÎ»(2,1)Î±Ì(xA,u)+Î¸+2Î¸Ì+2Î»(2,2)(xA,u). Here we have denoted the (Î¸+)n(Î¸Ì+)m-component as Î»(n,m)(xA,u). In the case of the singlet deformation, the gauge variation of V++WZ corresponding to this general gauge parameter is calculated as (15)Î´âÎV++WZ=ââ++Î»(0,0)+Î¸Ì+Î±Ìââ++Î»(0,1)Î±Ì+Î¸+Î±ââ++Î»(1,0)Î±+Î¸Ì+2iCsâÎ¼Î»(0,0)AÎ¼ââ++Î»(0,2)+Î¸+2ââ++Î»(2,0)+Î¸+ÏÎ¼Î¸Ì+2iâÎ¼Î»(0,0)+2iCsâÎ¼Î»(0,0)ÏÌââ++Î»Î¼(1,1)+Î¸Ì+2Î¸+Î±â2CsâÎ¼Î»(0,0)ÏÎ¼ÏÌiÎ±uâiâiÏÎ½âÎ½Î»(0,1)Î±âi2CsÏÎ½âÎ½Î»(0,1)Î±ÏÌ+i2CsÎ»(1,0)Î²ÏÎ¼ÏÌÎ½ÎµÎ²Î±âÎ¼AÎ½+iCsâÎ¼Î»(1,0)Î±AÎ¼ââ++Î»(1,2)Î±+Î¸+2Î¸Ì+Î±ÌiâÎ¼Î»(1,0)Î²ÏÎ¼Î²Î²ÌÎµÎ²ÌÎ±Ì+i2CsâÎ½Î»(1,0)Î±ÏÎ½Î±Î²ÌÎµÎ²ÌÎ±ÌÏÌââ++Î»(2,1)Î±Ì+Î¸+2Î¸Ì+2CsâÎ½Î»(1,0)Î±ÏÎ½ÏÌâÎ±iâÎ¼Î»Î¼(1,1)âi2CsâÎ¼Î»Î¼(1,1)ÏÌ+iCsâÎ¼Î»(2,0)AÎ¼ââ++Î»(2,2), where â++â¡u+iââuâi. Requiring that the analytic gauge parameter preserves the WZ gauge, we find that the gauge parameter should satisfy Î»(0,0)(xA,u)=Î»(xA) and the other components are zero. Namely, the analytic gauge parameter retaining the WZ gauge is of the same form as in the commutative case: (16)Î(Î¶,u)=Î»(xA). Then we immediately find the deformed gauge transformation laws for the component fields in the case of the singlet deformation: (17)Î´âÎAÎ¼=â1+12CsÏÌâÎ¼Î»,Î´âÎÏ=12CsAÎ¼âÎ¼Î»,Î´âÎÏiÎ±=â12CsâÎ¼Î»ÏÎ¼ÏÌiÎ±,Î´âÎÏÌ=Î´âÎÏÌiÎ±Ì=Î´âÎDij=0. Note that there is no higher order correction in Cs.

We will determine the supersymmetry transformation Î´Î¾ generated by the supersymmetry generators QiÎ±. First we consider the action of QiÎ± on the gauge superfield: (18)Î´ÌÎ¾V++WZâ¡Î¾iÎ±QiÎ±V++WZ. In the analytic basis, (19)Î¾iÎ±QiÎ±=âÎ¾+Î±QâÎ±+Î¾âÎ±Q+Î±, where Î¾Â±Î±â¡Î¾iÎ±uÂ±i and (20)Q+Î±=ââÎ¸âÎ±â2iÏÎ¼Î±Î±ÌÎ¸Ì+Î±ÌââxÎ¼A,QâÎ±=âââÎ¸+Î±. The variation is not affected by the nonanticommutativity, so that we have (21)Î´ÌÎ¾V++WZ=Î¸Ì+Î±Ì2iÎ¾+ÏÎ¼Î²ÌÎµÎ²ÌÎ±ÌAÎ¼+Î¸+Î±â22iÎ¾+Î±ÏÌ+Î¸Ì+24Î¾+Ïiuâi+Î¸+ÏÎ¼Î¸Ì+4Î¾+ÏÎ¼ÏÌiuâi+Î¸Ì+2Î¸+Î±â2ÏÎ¼ÏÌÎ½Î¾âÎ±âÎ½AÎ¼+6Î¾+Î±Dijuâiuâj+Î¸+2Î¸Ì+Î±Ì22Î¾âÏÎ¼Î²ÌÎµÎ²ÌÎ±ÌâÎ¼ÏÌ+Î¸+2Î¸Ì+2â4iÎ¾âÏÎ¼âÎ¼ÏÌiuâi. This is out of the WZ gauge, so in order to retain the WZ gauge it should be associated with an appropriate deformed gauge transformation Î´âÎ, as in the commutative case. From the result for the deformed gauge variation with the most general gauge parameter, (15), we can find that at least Î»(0,0) and Î»(2,0) should be zero. With the use of such an analytic gauge parameter, the equations to determine the deformed supersymmetric transformation of the component fields will be found from the equation (22)Î´Î¾V++WZ=Î´ÌÎ¾V++WZ+Î´âÎV++WZ. From those equations, we can find the appropriate gauge parameter is the one as same as in the Cs=0 case and determine the deformed supersymmetry transformations as (23)Î´Î¾AÎ¼=iÎ¾iÏÎ¼ÏÌi,Î´Î¾Ï=â2iÎ¾iÏi,Î´Î¾ÏÌ=0,Î´Î¾ÏiÎ±=1+12CsÏÌÏÎ¼Î½Î¾iÎ±FÎ¼Î½âDijÎ¾Î±j+12CsÎ¾iÎ±âÎ¼ÏÌAÎ¼,Î´Î¾ÏÌÎ±Ìi=â2ÏÌÎ¼Î¾iÎ±Ì1+12CsÏÌâÎ¼ÏÌ,Î´Î¾Dkl=âiÎ¾kÏÎ¼âÎ¼ÏÌl1+12CsÏÌâiÎ¾lÏÎ¼âÎ¼ÏÌk1+12CsÏÌ, where ÏÎ¼Î½â¡14(ÏÎ¼ÏÌÎ½âÏÎ½ÏÌÎ¼).

We have seen that the deformed gauge and supersymmetry transformations are exact at the order O(Cs). One may consider the component action which is invariant under these transformations. The variation of L(1) for the deformed gauge and supersymmetry transformations produces new terms of order O(Cs2), which should be cancelled by the variation of the O(Cs2) Lagrangian L(2). But it turns out that these deformed transformations change only the ÏÌ dependence of interaction terms among gauge fields and fermions. Since the spacetime coordinates have noncommutativity with nilpotent parameters, we expect that the Lagrangian do not include the higher derivative terms. Thus we assume the Lagrangian takes the form (24)L=f1(ÏÌ)FÎ¼Î½FÎ¼Î½+FÌÎ¼Î½+f2(ÏÌ)ÏiÏÎ¼âÎ¼ÏÌi+f3(ÏÌ)Ï+f4(ÏÌ)DijDij+f5(ÏÌ)AÎ¼ÏÌiÏÌÎ¼ÏÎ½âÎ½ÏÌi+f6(ÏÌ)AÎ¼âÎ½ÏÌFÎ¼Î½+FÌÎ¼Î½+f7(ÏÌ)AÎ¼AÎ¼+fÎ¼Î½8(ÏÌ)AÎ¼AÎ½+f9Î¼(ÏÌ)ÏiÏÎ¼ÏÌi+f10Î½(ÏÌ)AÎ¼ÏÌiÏÌÎ¼ÏÎ½ÏÌi+f11(ÏÌ)DijÏÌiÏÌj+f12(ÏÌ)(ÏÌiÏÌj)(ÏÌiÏÌj). Here fi are functions of ÏÌ and its derivatives. Invariance of the Lagrangian L under the deformed gauge transformation (17) imposes the constrains on the functions fi's. Similarly invariance under the deformed supersymmetry transformation (23) leads to the further constraints on fi's. From the set of those constrains, fi's are solved by the function f2. Therefore the Lagrangian becomes (25)L=if2(ÏÌ)â141+12CsÏÌFÎ¼Î½FÎ¼Î½+FÌÎ¼Î½âiÏiÏÎ¼âÎ¼ÏÌi+1+12CsÏÌâ2ÏÌÏ+1411+12CsÏÌDijDijâiCs21+12CsÏÌAÎ¼ÏÌkÏÌÎ¼ÏÎ½âÎ½ÏÌkâ12CsAÎ¼âÎ½ÏFÎ¼Î½+FÌÎ¼Î½+Cs22âÎ¼âÎ¼ÏÌâCs21+12CsÏÌâÎ¼ÏÌâÎ¼ÏÌAÎ¼AÎ¼+14Cs21+12CsÏÌâÎ¼ÏÌâÎ½ÏÌAÎ¼AÎ½+iCs21+12CsÏÌâÎ¼ÏÌÏkÏÎ¼ÏÌk+iCs2221+12CsÏÌ2âÎ½ÏÌAÎ¼ÏÌkÏÌÎ¼ÏÎ½ÏÌk+i2Cs1+12CsÏÌ2DijÏÌiÏÌjâ14Cs21+12CsÏÌ3ÏÌiÏÌjÏÌiÏÌj. At the order O(Cs), the Lagrangian reduced to the result (13) due to f2=âi(1â12CsÏÌ)+O(Cs2).

Now we consider the field redefinition. In the singlet deformation case, the O(Cs) gauge transformation (17) is exact. We can redefine the component fields such that these transform canonically under the deformed gauge transformation. Let us introduce AÌÎ¼, ÏÌ and ÏÌi by (26)AÌÎ¼=F(ÏÌ)AÎ¼,ÏÌ=Ï+G(ÏÌ)AÎ¼AÎ¼,ÏÌiÎ±=Ïi+H(ÏÌ)AÎ¼ÏÎ¼ÏÌiÎ±, where F(ÏÌ), G(ÏÌ) and H(ÏÌ) are functions of ÏÌ. If we require that these fields transform canonically, i.e., Î´Î»AÌÎ¼=ââÎ¼Î», and Î´Î»ÏÌ=Î´Î»ÏÌi=0, then the functions F, G and H are determined as (27)F(ÏÌ)=11+12CsÏÌ,G(ÏÌ)=122Cs1+12CsÏÌ,H(ÏÌ)=â12Cs1+12CsÏÌ. It is easy to see that the Lagrangian (25) after the field redefinitions (26) also coincides with the O(Cs) result in [12].

The N=2 vector multiplet (Dij,AÌÎ¼,ÏÌi,ÏÌi,ÏÌ,ÏÌ), however, does not transform canonically under the supersymmetry transformation. But, if we instead perform field redefinitions as (28)aÎ¼=F(ÏÌ)AÎ¼,Ï=F(ÏÌ)2Ï+G(ÏÌ)AÎ¼AÎ¼,ÏÌ=ÏÌ,Î»iÎ±=F(ÏÌ)2ÏiÎ±+H(ÏÌ)AÎ¼ÏÎ¼ÏÌiÎ±,Î»ÌÎ±Ìi=F(ÏÌ)ÏÌÎ±Ìi,DÌij=F(ÏÌ)2Dijâ2iH(ÏÌ)ÏÌiÏÌj, we can show that the multiplet (DÌij,aÎ¼,Î»i,Î»Ìi,Ï,ÏÌ) now transforms canonically under the supersymmetry transformation as well as the gauge transformation: (29)Î´Î¾aÎ¼=iÎ¾iÏÎ¼Î»Ìi,Î´Î¾Ï=âi2Î¾iÎ»i,Î´Î¾ÏÌ=0,Î´Î¾Î»iÎ±=ÏÎ¼Î½Î¾iÎ±fÎ¼Î½âDÌijÎ¾jÎ±,Î´Î¾Î»ÌÎ±Ìi=â2ÏÌÎ¼Î¾iÎ±ÌâÎ¼ÏÌ,Î´Î¾DÌij=âiÎ¾iÏÎ¼âÎ¼Î»Ìj+Î¾jÏÎ¼âÎ¼Î»Ìi, here fÎ¼Î½â¡âÎ¼aÎ½ââÎ½aÎ¼. In terms of these newly defined fields, the Lagrangian becomes (30)L=if2(ÏÌ)1+12CsÏÌ3â14fÎ¼Î½fÎ¼Î½+fÌÎ¼Î½âiÎ»iÏÎ¼âÎ¼Î»Ìi+Ïâ2ÏÌ+14DÌijDÌij, which takes a simple form.

In this Letter, we have determined the deformed gauge and supersymmetry transformation of component fields of N=2 supersymmetric U(1) gauge theory in the noncommutative harmonic superspace with the singlet deformation parameter. The Lagrangian which is invariant under these transformations are obtained. In this Letter, we could not determine the complete Lagrangian due to the function f2(ÏÌ), which is necessary for further study. We have studied the field redefinition of component fields, such that these fields transform canonically under the gauge transformation. It is interesting to compare the present result to the Lagrangian in [11], which is based on the different Poisson structure.

It is also interesting to study the deformed supersymmetry in the case of nonsinglet deformation. We expect that the action is invariant under the deformed N=(1,0) supersymmetry. In this case one may consider the N=1/2 superspace limit by restricting CÎ±Î²ij to CÎ±Î²Î´1iÎ´1j. The action in this limit is expected to reduce to that in [6], in which it was claimed that the N=2 action has only N=1/2 supersymmetry. In [6], the supersymmetry linearly deformed in C has been examined. But the reduction from the harmonic superspace suggests that the deformed supersymmetry is realized nonlinearly in C. In a subsequent paper [18], we will study the structure of supersymmetry for generic deformation parameters and clarify this point.

ce:section.ce:para: After this Letter was submitted to the e-archive, a new paper has appeared [19] where the undetermined function in the component Lagrangian is completely fixed.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: We would like to thank A. Ohtsuka for useful discussion. One of the authors (T.A.) is supported by the Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research in Priority Areas (No.Â 14046201) from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Science, Sports and Technology of Japan.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: T. Araki, K. Ito, A. Ohtsuka, in preparation
